issue.title: where Hunter save (as default) Environment's key?

labels.name: Duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: hyperparameter_hunter
repository.description: Easy hyperparameter optimization and automatic result saving across machine learning algorithms and libraries

issue.body:
HI

where hunter save (as default) Environment's key?
because not in path specified in 'root_results_path' param;
then what if I need to reset or delete that Environment's key?
in fact if I rerun the same script (after deleting all files in "root_results_path" folder), many experiments are not saved in 'optimizer.similar_experiments', infact
"assert experiment.experiment_id in [_[2] for _ in optimizer.similar_experiments]"  raise Exception;

another question: why 'GlobalLeaderboard.csv' stores experiments in descending order also when using metrics like 'mean_squared_error'?
 then it report me the worse model as the best (with higher mean_squared_error score)...

thanks

issue.title: hyperparameter space issue

repository.name: hyperparameter_hunter
repository.description: Easy hyperparameter optimization and automatic result saving across machine learning algorithms and libraries

issue.body:
HI
ther's a problem when You try to rerun the optimizer with 'exactly' the same
 hyperparameters's range of values;

for example, if I declare: 
'max_depth'=Integer(2, 15) 
and any other Real hyperpar., for ex.:
 'min_split_loss'=(...)
 the  hyper_space_size will be: np.inf;

then it make sense to rerun optimizer  also with high interations(in the same space);
but if I try to do that, the following Uncaught exception occur:

"Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:/MachinLrn/Esperiments_Prjct/scripts/one.py", line 135, in <module>
    execute()
  File "D:/MachinLrn/Esperiments_Prjct/scripts/one.py", line 109, in execute
    optimizer.go()  # Now, we go
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization.py", line 87, in go
    super().go()
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization_core.py", line 340, in go
    self._optimization_loop()
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization_core.py", line 364, in _optimization_loop
    if len(self.similar_experiments) + len(self.tested_keys) >= self.search_space_size:
  File "D:\software\Anaconda3\envs\RBM\lib\site-packages\hyperparameter_hunter\optimization_core.py", line 802, in search_space_size
    self._search_space_size = len(self.hyperparameter_space)
TypeError: 'float' object cannot be interpreted as an integer

then if I change the max_depth range , like (2, 14) and rerun optimizer, all works well, again...

body: This is also mentioned by @caprone in #87.

A temporary workaround for this is to provide a callable to the `metrics_map` argument of `Environment` that returns the negation of the metric you want to use. For example, if your environment looks like this:
```python
env = Environment(
   ...
   metrics_map=['mean_squared_error'],
   ...
)
```
Your leaderboards will be ordered backwards, and OptimizationProtocols will move in the wrong direction. Instead, for now, use the following:
```python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

env = Environment(
   ...
   metrics_map=dict(mean_squared_error=lambda t, p: -mean_squared_error(t, p)),
   ...
)
```
This has the side effect of including a negative sign before the metric values, but everything works as expected.

thanks HunterMcGushion !
a solution that nevertheless achieves its purpose!

issue.title: Bidirectional optimization metrics

repository.name: hyperparameter_hunter
repository.description: Easy hyperparameter optimization and automatic result saving across machine learning algorithms and libraries

issue.body:
- Intended to address #34 
- Introduces wrapper classes for `Metric` and `MetricMap` to which the `metrics_map` kwarg of `environment.Environment.__init__` will be automatically converted
- New `Metric` class has `direction` parameter, which will be used to minimize metric values during optimization/leaderboard sorting when the metric is a measure of loss/error
   - `direction` can be set to "infer", which will choose to minimize the metric when its `name` contains the string "loss", or "error". In all other cases, it will default to "max" the metric
- Can continue to provide `metrics_map` as before, and it will be automatically converted to the new class, or can directly provide the new classes for more customization

issue.title: HPH Regression?

repository.name: hyperparameter_hunter
repository.description: Easy hyperparameter optimization and automatic result saving across machine learning algorithms and libraries

issue.body:
Hi,
     We just finished a nasty but eventually successful 9-month search for a high-dimension, very non-linear, chock full of outliers, real world regression modeling problem.  While we have a breather for a few days we're looking for a smarter way to evaluate and tune parameters for as many approaches as possible while we wait for our next problem to drop. 
    We like the approach of HPH and we see support for XGBRegressor and SKLearn-wrapped Keras Regressor but no example of hyper-parameter experiments or optimization with regression rather then classification.  Missing something obvious? Example? Or wrong tool (at least for now)?

thanks
